channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: For the Lost Children of Tuam, a Proper Burial at Last
item.description: Hundreds of small bodies were buried under a playground at a home for unwed mothers, many in a disused sewage system. Years after Ireland acknowledged the grim discovery, a resolution is finally near.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry
item.category: Bon Secours Mother and Baby Home (Tuam, Ireland)
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: The grounds of the former “mother and baby” home operated by the Sisters of Bon Secours from 1925 to 1961 in Tuam, Ireland.

item.title: In Liberia and Across Africa, Viktor Bout’s Bloody Legacy Is Still Felt
item.description: The Russian arms dealer swapped for Brittney Griner was convicted of conspiring to kill Americans. But in the 1990s and early 2000s, he supplied weapons to myriad African conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Dounard Bondo
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: U.S. Department of Justice, via Reuters
item.media:description: The Russian arms dealer Viktor Bout arriving in New York from Thailand in 2010 after he was arrested in a sting operation.

item.title: Peru Declares National State of Emergency Amid Deadly Protests
item.description: The measure suspended some civil rights, including the freedom of assembly, and deepens a crisis set off when the elected president was impeached by Congress last week.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: Members of Indigenous communities and farmers during a protest in Cuzco, Peru, against the removal of former President Pedro Castillo.

item.title: How Will China Fare With Covid? ‘Meaningless’ Data Clouds the Picture.
item.description: Despite assurances that the situation is under control, information on infections has become more opaque now that Beijing has rolled back pandemic restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
item.media:description: Outbreaks continued in Shanghai on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia Attacks Kyiv with a Wave of Iranian-Made Drones After a Lull
item.description: Analysts had surmised that Russia was having trouble with the drones, but if a problem has been fixed, it remains unclear how long the Kremlin can sustain such attacks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A damaged building after a Russian drone attack on Wednesday in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: ‘Banksy of Borovsk,’ a Russian Muralist, Wages His Own War
item.description: An 84-year-old artist, defying Moscow’s crackdown on dissent, wants his country to acknowledge misdeeds both past and present.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: As Strikes Expand, Britain Faces a New ‘Winter of Discontent’
item.description: In the 1970s, Margaret Thatcher accused the Labour government of losing control. Now, the same charge is being leveled by Labour against the Conservatives.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: British railway workers walked off the job on Tuesday, kicking off what is expected to be a month of strikes by public service workers. Foot traffic was still light at Waterloo station in London on Wednesday.

item.title: What to Know About the Political Turmoil in Peru
item.description: An impeachment vote, an arrest, a new president, a national state of emergency. An initially peaceful transfer of power turned violent in this fragile South American democracy.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Marco Garro for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police fired tear gas to disperse crowds of supporters of Pedro Castillo, now Peru’s former president, after he was arrested on Dec. 7.

item.title: Iran Ousted From UN Women’s Rights Agency in US-backed Vote
item.description: The resolution was the strongest symbolic gesture so far by the U.N. in response to Iran’s efforts to crack down on a women-led uprising now in its third month.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Member countries voting on the removal of Iran from the Commission on the Status of Women on Wednesday at United Nations headquarters in New York.

item.title: Istanbul Mayor Jailed for Insulting Public Officials, Barring Him From Politics
item.description: The mayor of Istanbul, a possible rival to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in the 2023 elections, was convicted of insulting public officials.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur

item.title: At Least 4 Dead as Boat Capsizes in English Channel
item.description: British and French maritime authorities were carrying out a major rescue operation, a day after Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain announced new plans to slow such crossings.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Migrants picked up at sea while trying to cross the English Channel were escorted from a British patrol boat in Dover, southeastern England, on Wednesday.

item.title: Two Dogs from North Korea Become Victims of a Political Squabble
item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un gave two pups to South Korea as a symbol of peace. Now the canines are at the center of a political spat between leaders in the South.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: South Korea Presidential Blue House, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea and Gomi, a Pungsan dog given by North Korea, in Seoul, in 2018.

item.title: At Least 141 Die in Congo After Floods Hit Kinshasa
item.description: In Kinshasa, a megacity of 15 million, heavy rain left roads, infrastructure and many neighborhoods underwater or in ruins.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: The muddy aftermath of heavy rains, flooding and landslides on the outskirts of Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, on Tuesday.

item.title: New Zealand Bans Cigarette Sales to Everyone Born After 2008
item.description: The new laws are aimed at eliminating most smoking by 2025 and slashing the number of licensed tobacco retailers.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Cigarettes for sale in Auckland, New Zealand, in 2014.

item.title: Zelensky Urges Barring Russian and Belarusian Athletes from 2024 Olympics
item.description: In recent days, international Olympic officials have been unclear about whether the athletes will be allowed to compete in the Paris Summer Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian medalists from the Moscow Winter Olympics in 2018.

item.title: Argentina’s Most Sacred World Cup Watch Party: Maradona’s Former Home
item.description: A Buenos Aires businessman bought Diego Maradona’s old house and has been opening it up for Argentina’s World Cup matches, meat included.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Sarah Pabst
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Argentine soccer fans celebrating a goal during a watch party at Maradona’s former home on Tuesday in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Brussels Court Orders 3 Linked to Qatar Bribery Case to Stay in Prison
item.description: Belgian officials said they suspected a Gulf country of trying “to influence the economic and political decisions of the European Parliament.”
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Eva Kaili was stripped of her title as a vice president of the European Parliament after she was charged with corruption, money laundering and participation in suspected bribes from Qatar.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: China’s Snarled Covid Data
item.description: Plus France just beat Morocco to advance to the World Cup finals.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Outbreaks continued in Shanghai on Tuesday.

item.title: Zelensky Calls for War Tribunal for Russia’s ‘Crime of Aggression’
item.description: Ukraine’s president made the remarks as he accepted the union’s top human rights award on behalf of his people.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Roberta Metsola, president of the European Parliament, reacting to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky during his acceptance of the Sakharov prize, the European Union’s top human rights award.

item.title: US Wants to Counter China’s Moves in Africa, But Officials Try Not to Mention That
item.description: President Biden and his aides do not want the nearly 50 African leaders attending the event to perceive that official U.S. interests on the continent are mainly driven by a desire to counter China.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong

item.title: Rwanda’s President Says the US Can’t ‘Bully’ Him Into Releasing Rusesabagina
item.description: President Paul Kagame of Rwanda suggested that only an invasion of his country could force him to release Paul Rusesabagina, a rescuer in the 1994 Rwandan genocide.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Paul Kagame of Rwanda delivers remarks during the Space Forum at the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit on Tuesday.

item.title: China Withdraws 6 Diplomats From U.K. After Consulate Scuffle
item.description: The British government had asked the Chinese officials to waive their diplomatic immunity and allow an investigation into how a pro-democracy protester was beaten.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Matthew Leung/The Chaser News, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A pro-democracy protester was dragged into the grounds of the Chinese Consulate in Manchester, England, during demonstrations in October.

item.title: In Fiji’s Closely Observed Election, the Incumbent Takes the Lead
item.description: In a region where China and the United States fight for influence, observers await results from the vote to choose the island nation’s prime minister — and to see if the outcome will be respected.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Sitiveni Rabuka, center, lining up to vote in Suva, Fiji, on Wednesday. His People’s Alliance party led in early results.

item.title: Grant Wahl Died of a Burst Blood Vessel, His Family Says
item.description: An autopsy in New York showed that the journalist had a tear in the ascending aorta, a large vessel that carries blood from the heart.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Andrew Das
item.media:credit: Doug Zimmerman/ISI Photos, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The sports journalist Grant Wahl covering the Wales-U.S. World Cup match on Nov. 21 at Ahmad bin Ali Stadium in Qatar. He collapsed and died on Friday.

item.title: Pope Francis Calls for ‘Humble’ Christmas and Urges Donating to Ukraine
item.description: “Let us not forget Christmas,” the pope said at the end of his weekly general audience, “but with the people of Ukraine in our hearts, and let us offer concrete signs of help for them.”
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving at the weekly general audience at the Vatican on Wednesday.

item.title: Turning Sci-fi Into Reality
item.description: Scientists announced a nuclear fusion breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Inspecting a final optics assembly at the National Ignition Facility.

item.title: Russia’s ‘Sham’ Charge of Spying Makes Whelan’s Case the Hardest
item.description: Supporters say Paul Whelan is more hapless tourist than James Bond — and that the Russians know it. But that doesn’t make freeing him any easier.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Supporters of Paul Whelan and analysts say there is no clear path for his release from detention in Russia.

item.title: They Fought the Lawn. And the Lawn Lost.
item.description: After their homeowner association ordered them to replace their wildlife-friendly plants with turf grass, a Maryland couple sued. They ended up changing state law.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Jason Andrew
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

item.title: A Powerful Climate Leader From a Small Island Nation
item.description: Mia Mottley, the prime minister of Barbados, has been drawing attention to the environmental and financial threats faced by small and vulnerable countries like hers.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Mia Mottley, the prime minister of Barbados, at the Nelson Mandela Lecture in South Africa in November.

item.title: A New Figure Emerges to Shake Up Georgia’s Status Quo
item.description: With the country’s politics ‘on hold’ during Russia’s war on Ukraine, Anna Dolidze is awaiting her turn to lead on grass roots issues.
item.dc:creator: Celestine Bohlen
item.media:credit: Daro Sulakauri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Dolidze broadcasting live on Facebook from a bus station in Tbilisi, Georgia, on Dec. 2. Some attribute her visibility to her presence on social media, where she speaks about issues affecting average citizens.

item.title: Countries Pledge $1 Billion in Aid for Ukraine
item.description: A French-led effort to involve dozens of countries aims to help Ukraine survive a harsh winter with quick repair of vital electrical, heating, water and health care systems.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: World leaders on Tuesday announced more than $1 billion in swift aid for Ukraine to repair the destroyed country.

item.title: France vs. Morocco: Joy and Anxiety Collide Before World Cup Semifinal
item.description: Morocco’s magical run has elated fans, but for some, the strain of the impending showdown with the country’s former colonial overlords is too much.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Aida Alami
item.media:credit: Imane Djamil for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ksar el Kebir has made efforts to develop Moroccan soccer talent: new sports academies, new stadiums and new training programs.

item.title: Biden Hosts African Leaders for Talks on Security, Trade and Outer Space
item.description: Nearly 50 African heads of state are attending the first U.S.-Africa summit since 2014. It opened with sessions on civil conflict, democracy and space exploration.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The first day of meetings at the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit centered on critical topics including the environment, public health, democratic governance and security.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Nuclear Fusion Breakthrough
item.description: Plus Argentina beat Croatia to advance to the World Cup finals.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: An inspection of a final optics assembly during routine maintenance at the National Ignition Facility of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California.

item.title: Prince Accused of Plot in Germany Is Said to Have Visited Russian Diplomats
item.description: Closed briefings by police investigators divulged extensive new plot details to German lawmakers — from death vows to caches of bullets.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prince Heinrich XIII of Reuss’s Waidmannsheil lodge in Bad Lobenstein, Germany.

item.title: Ukraine Targets Melitopol, Hinting at Next Front in the War with Russia
item.description: Using missiles and saboteurs, Ukraine is focusing on the city of Melitopol, a vital Russian link to Crimea, ahead of an expected southern offensive.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The site of a car bomb explosion outside a building housing a local TV station in Melitopol in October.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Unveils Plans to Tackle Migrant Boat Crossings and Asylum Backlog
item.description: Amid growing anger within his governing Conservative Party, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak vowed to eliminate the country’s backlog of asylum claims.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A lifeboat on the southeast coast of Britain with migrants picked up at sea while attempting to cross the English Channel in June.

item.title: As Morocco and France Prepare for World Cup, Historical Tensions Swirl
item.description: Wednesday’s face-off between the Atlas Lions and Les Bleus will be about more than just soccer, reviving old colonial wounds and fueling identity debates.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Tom Nouvian
item.media:description: Morocco supporters in Paris celebrating the team’s win over Portugal to reach the semifinals in the World Cup.

item.title: French Court Convicts 8 of Aiding 2016 Terrorist Attack in Nice
item.description: The defendants were found guilty of helping the perpetrator prepare for the assault in which he plowed a truck into a Bastille Day crowd, killing 86 people.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in Nice, in southern France, to the victims of the terrorist attack that killed 86 people in 2016.

item.title: Violence Grows in Peru After President Pedro Castillo Is Ousted
item.description: At least six people have been killed in violence that has spread across the country following last week’s impeachment of Pedro Castillo after he tried to dissolve Congress.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj, Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Supporters of former President Pedro Castillo clashing with riot police during a protest near the Congress in Lima, Peru, on Monday.

item.title: In Libya, Mystery Shrouds Handover of Lockerbie Suspect to US
item.description: Abu Agila Mohammad Mas’ud, a former intelligence officer accused of delivering the bomb that destroyed a passenger jet mid flight in 1988, was abducted from his home, according to relatives.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Paul Hudson with a picture of his daughter, Melina, and photographs of almost 100 other victims of the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, outside a Washington courthouse on Monday.

item.title: South Africa Rejects Impeachment Inquiry of President Cyril Ramaphosa
item.description: Legislators with the African National Congress party voted not to hold impeachment hearings of their embattled president, Cyril Ramaphosa, giving him a political lift amid the scandal known as “Farmgate.”
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa came under scrutiny after he failed to inform police about a break-in at this farm.

item.title: Belarus Checks Army Readiness as Analysts Say It Is Unlikely to Join Ukraine War
item.description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus is a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, and Belarus relies on Moscow for finance, fuel and security assistance.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus is a close ally of Russia.

item.title: Concern Grows in Israel’s Military as Netanyahu Nears Coalition Deal
item.description: Preliminary agreements between Benjamin Netanyahu and his far-right allies have raised questions about political interference in the army’s chain of command.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu has held coalition talks that could see parts of the military hierarchy in the West Bank placed under the authority of two far-right politicians.

item.title: Removal of Banksy Work in Ukraine Sparks Debate Around the Future Of His Murals
item.description: The removal of a Banksy mural sparks a debate about the future of a handful of his works scattered in and around Ukraine’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A dancer posing near a stenciled painting attributed to Banksy. The work shows a gymnast appearing to do a handstand on the rubble of a destroyed building in Borodianka, near the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv.

item.title: Europe Reaches Deal for Carbon Tax Law on Imports
item.description: If approved, as expected, the plan would impose tariffs on countries that fail to take strict steps to curb their greenhouse gas emissions.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:description: A steel factory in Shanghai in September. China would be affected by the new law, alongside other E.U. trade partners.

item.title: Somalis Are Dying of Hunger. Officials Say It’s Not a Famine. Why?
item.description: An official declaration of famine would unleash aid and attention. Some experts say Somalia shows that the international system for making the judgment is broken.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ali Muhammed held his 3-year-old son Isaac at a nutrition center run by Save the Children and World Vision in Baidoa, Somalia, last month.

item.title: Indian and Chinese Soldiers Again Trade Blows at Disputed Border
item.description: Tensions are still simmering two years after a deadly confrontation over a remote region each country claims as its own.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: A convoy of Indian Army trucks traveling a road to the Tawang area in the Indian state of Arunachal Pradesh last year.

item.title: As Covid Spreads Fast in China, Beijing Isn’t in Lockdown. But It Feels Like It.
item.description: Almost no one is venturing out even after an easing of pandemic measures. Cold and flu medicines are scarce, but food supplies appear adequate.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and David Pierson
item.media:description: Delivery drivers, usually ubiquitous in Beijing, have nearly vanished because of Covid infections.

item.title: Jin, Eldest BTS Member, Enlists in South Korean Army
item.description: Saying goodbye to the ARMY — as the K-pop supergroup’s fan base is known — and hello to the armed forces, Jin became the first member of the boy band to start mandatory military service.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A fan of BTS singer Jin holding up his photo in front of a military training facility in Gyeonggi Province, South Korea, where he began his mandatory military service.

item.title: ‘There Must Be More Room for Africa,’ Leader of African Union Says
item.description: President Macky Sall of Senegal, chairman of the bloc, said in an interview before the U.S.-Africa summit that it’s time for the continent to have more seats in global institutions.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times
item.media:description: Macky Sall, president of the Republic of Senegal since 2012 and current chairman of the African Union, last week at the presidential palace in Dakar, the capital.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX, has been arrested and will face criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Bankman-Fried in the Bahamas in April.

item.title: Day 13: For a Celebrated Chef, the Tastes and Smells of St. Lucia Day in Sweden Linger
item.description: In his restaurants, including his latest, Marcus Samuelsson draws inspiration from childhood memories of the Scandinavian holiday.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Samuelsson

item.title: 6 Dead, Including 2 Officers, After Shootout in Rural Australia
item.description: The officers and a bystander were gunned down outside a property in Queensland, and the assailants were later killed by the police, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jason O'Brien/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press

item.title: Putin Skips Annual News Conference, Avoiding Possible Questions on War
item.description: The December event has offered reporters rare — albeit stage-managed — chances to pose hard questions. With the war going poorly for Russia, that could have been awkward.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after his year-end news conference in Moscow last December.

item.title: EU Imposes New Sanctions on Iranians Over Supplying Drones to Russia
item.description: Russia has deployed Iranian-made drones in Ukraine since August to attack infrastructure as well as military targets, according to U.S. officials.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a residential building in Kyiv, Ukraine, where an Iranian drone struck in October.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China’s Space Push
item.description: Plus China’s vaccination pivot and the year’s most stylish “people.”
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Chinese astronauts embarked on the Shenzhou 15 rocket on Nov. 29.

item.title: E.U. Roiled by Corruption Investigation Linked to Qatar
item.description: The bloc’s parliament and its executive body are scrambling to manage the fallout as the Belgian authorities continue raids linked to suspected illegal lobbying.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Roberta Metsola, president of the European Parliament, addressing lawmakers in Strasbourg, France, on Monday.
